item.title: Review of "The Book of Ruby"
item.dc:creator: Victor Goff
item.content:encoded:
Review of "The Book of Ruby" by Huw Collingbourne

TL;DR Good book, not without its pain points, and not totally for the beginner of Ruby, though there are some definite juicy parts that I would share with them, some of which are noted in a list near the end of this post.

  This review is written by Victor Goff.


  First things I noticed about the book is the table of contents and it is looking very good. It is well organized and chock full of goodies. As far as the index goes it is very good also.  

  The second thing I did was flipped through the book looking at the code snippets (It is a programming book after all) and noticed that apparently quite a few people had provided code, as the style is pretty consistently not consistent with indentation, and even block styles. It goes deeper, even the use of parentheses around puts calls is not consistent, sometimes they are there (actually very often) and sometimes they are not. Seldom it is to show the occasional places that it is required to get away from ambiguity.

  However, upon starting to read the book, and Mr. Collingbourne's notice that this book "does not preach on matters of style.", indeed, it sometimes seems to not follow its own style.  Having completed the reading of this book, I can confirm that for me, it was somewhat distracting.

  There was some other distracting things about the book, but I think (hope) in further editions they may be alleviated. Two samples are below.

  Page 126: Problem: Using Integer to prove assignment of a variable doesn't affect the object ID is not a proof. It is good though that shortly after the examples, he does mention that Integers are 'special'. It would be better if a String or some other mutable object were used to provide the point earlier, instead of using integers though.  He isn't the only one that does this example... I have seen it in a lot of places in the web, and each gives me the same bad taste.

  Related to the above, he even suggests that the object_id of 10 is 21, and 23 is the object_id of 11, and that it may vary. This is not the case, the object_id will not vary, and can lead students down the wrong path, the wrong assumptions if they aren't familiar with what he explains starting on the following page. And that is that Integers are special. Their ID doesn't change.

  So it is things like this that cause me to not trust the other information. Even though the next page he reverses his statement of 'may be' to how Integer is special, and those ids never change.

  There was also information I expected to be there in the Digging Deeper sections, though they were mostly tasty, that was missing. For example 'next' for blocks wasn't discussed, and allocate method wasn't covered. Just a few notable exclusions. But understandably, you can't cover everything in a book.  

  If you are comfortable with Ruby, and willing to proof the concepts here, it is very likely you will learn some new things. It will likely help to make your understanding of Ruby more complete.  One such area of "proof this" exists in the Digging Deeper section for Chapter 6, where it is presented that:

will error in Ruby 1.8. And it will. But only because of his habit of (usually) placing parenthesis directly after puts.  If you were to use:

You will find that it is perfectly legal in Ruby 1.8.

Examine the following test in IRB:

Will give you this error:

And finally:

Gives you this error:

All of the samples ran using this version:

  As you see, the premise is actually truthful.  And if you are paying close attention here you will realize that there is something going on that may be easy to miss (I just wish he would expound on this) and that is the fact that an open parenthesis right next to your method means something different than a parenthesis one space away.  puts( is different than puts ( in how the parser parses the code.  It is hard to see this if you are new to Ruby and may cause confusion.  If you have some experience then it isn't so hard to see what is going on.

  A friend of mine asked me if I couldn't write something different in this review... some more positive oriented points.

  I hope that this review doesn't portray the message that I thought the book was terrible, or bad.  It really isn't.  I just can't see handing this book to someone new to Ruby and stating "This is the book for you!  Read it and work through the presented examples, and you will understand Ruby."  It is possible that this would happen, but because of the inconsistencies, the lack of experience of that person to make informed opinions of where style is important, some of the potential goose chases presented in the book, and the 'proof this' areas, without walking through some of these ares, makes it a book that may confuse more than enlighten.

  I won't list all of the sections where a beginner to Ruby would benefit, but a couple of notable inclusions would be:
 * A quick overview of Documenting Ruby with RDoc that gives a quick and not-in-depth introduction to RDoc.
 * The same for Apendix  B, a quick set of instructions for "Installing MySQL for Ruby on Rails"     

 * Speaking of Rails, about 24 pages or so of Ruby On Rails, just enough to get your teeth into it

The long and the short of it.  If you are just learning Ruby there are less frustrating books to purchase.  Having said that, if you have some experience with Ruby, and are wanting a good reference book, and wanting to exercise your skepticism, it is a good book.  It definitely forced me to learn a bit more, and that is never a bad thing.

  I will use it as a reference, it will stay in my library of books on Ruby.  It has value, and it has insights.  There is no question of that.  I will likely even read it again.

item.dc:creator: Victor Goff (Google+)
item.content:encoded:
Victor Goff shared a post with you on Google+. Google+ makes sharing on the web more like sharing in real life. Learn more.
Join Google+
Things I may require to write an internal DSL in Ruby
(My notes as I develop a DSL I have in mind)

1.0 Introduction
(Reference: A Little Language for Surveys: Constructing an Internal DSL in Ruby)

DSLs are usually small, declarative languages targeted at end users or domain specialists who are not expert programmers. Fowler classifies DSLs into two styles - external and internal. An external DSL is a language that is different from the main programming language for an application, but that is interpreted by or translated into a program in the main language. An internal DSL transforms the main programming language itself into the DSL.

In the Ruby environment, there is significant interest in developing internal DSLs that are made possible by the extensive reflexive meta-programming facilities of Ruby.

Ruby has two groups of features that especially support defining internal DSLs - its flexible syntax and its support for blocks (i.e., closures).

For Ruby's flexible syntax of special importance is the syntax for method calls because methods are the primary means for adding operators and declarators - the verbs - to an internal DSL. Ruby method calls are flexible in three key ways:
a. the parentheses enclosing argument lists are optional,
b. methods may have a variable number of arguments,
c. and the use of hash data structures in argument lists provides a mechanism similar to keyword arguments.

Any Ruby method call may have a block attached. A block is a group of executable statements defined in the environment of the caller and passed un-evaluated as an implicit argument to the called method. The called method may then execute the block zero or more times, supplying any needed arguments for each call. The block executes with access to the environment in which
it was defined.

Reflexive meta-programming is possible primarily because Ruby is an interpreted language whose interpreter provides programmers with hooks into its internal state. Ruby’s facilities include the ability to query an object to determine its methods, instance variables, and class.


2.0 Useful Ruby stuff
a. Ruby Blocks
Ruby Code blocks (called closures in other languages) are chunks of code between braces or between do- end that you can associate with method invocations, almost as if they were parameters. A Ruby block is a way of grouping statements, and may appear only in the source adjacent to a method call; the block is written starting on the same line as the method call's last parameter (or the closing parenthesis of the parameter list). The code in the block is not executed at the time it is encountered. Instead, Ruby remembers the context in which the block appears (the local variables, the current object, and so on) and then enters the method.

Within a method, you can ask Ruby whether the current call includes a block. You can do that with the Object#block_given? method:
if block_given?

Matz says that any method can be called with a block as an implicit argument. Inside the method, you can call the block using the yield keyword with a value.

b. Blocks and Bindings
Entities like local variables, instance variables, self. . . are basically names bound to objects. We call them bindings.


Observe that the code in the block sees the person variable that was around when the block was defined, not the method's person variable. When you define the block, it simply grabs the bindings that are there at that moment, and then it carries those bindings along when you pass the block into a method. Hence a block captures the local bindings and carries them along with it. Because of this property, a computer scientist would say that a block is a closure. You can also define additional bindings inside the block, but they disappear after the block ends. Thus blocks contain both the code and a set of bindings.

c. Blocks and Procs
Ruby’s blocks are chunks of code attached to a method. Blocks are not objects, but they can be converted into objects of class Proc. This can be done by calling the lambda method of the class Object. A block created with lambda acts like a Ruby method. Some of the ways a block can be converted to a Proc object:

- By passing a block to a method whose last parameter is prefixed with an ampersand. That parameter will receive the block as a Proc object:
def my_method(p1, &block); end
This creates a "raw" proc which is basically designed to work as a body of control structures such as loops.

- By calling the method Object#lambda, associating a block with the call:
p lambda { |x| "Hello #{x}!" }.call 'World'
This creates a "lambdas" object, which is intended to act like a method.

d. send
send is an instance method of the Object class. The first argument to send is the message that you're sending to the object - that is, the name of a method. You can use a string or a symbol, but symbols are preferred. Any remaining arguments are simply passed on to the method:
